## [The Cost of Javascript in 2019](https://v8.dev/blog/cost-of-javascript-2019)

### High level guidance

The fact is that JS parses/compiles very fast in browsers. What you want to do is decrease the time for each JS bundle to load. So, it's vital to have many smaller JS bundles rather than one large one. You should utilise the [Long Tasks API](https://w3c.github.io/longtasks/) to identify all tasks that take over 50ms and gradually eliminate them. And, large inline scripts should be avoided.

![what long tasks look like](https://v8.dev/_img/cost-of-javascript-2019/long-tasks@2x.png)

#### Interesting notes about asynchronously loaded script tags

> Chrome started parsing async and deferred scripts on a separate thread as soon as the download begins.

> Chrome uses a task-based setup where the scheduler could parse multiple async/deferred scripts at once (each task appears to be ~30kb of JS, only beginning when 30kb is chunked).

#### Chrome 69 -> 78

69:

![performance devtools chrome 69](https://v8.dev/_img/cost-of-javascript-2019/devtools-69@2x.png)

78:

![perfomance devtools chrome 78](https://v8.dev/_img/cost-of-javascript-2019/devtools-76@2x.png)

#### A nuance about parsing JSON

This: `const data = { foo: 42, bar: 1337 }; // 🐌` (during run-time) is much slower than this: `const data = JSON.parse('{"foo":42,"bar":1337}'); // 🚀` so if you have a large object full of data to load, it would be better to utilise `JSON.parse`.

## And beyond that, some stuff about Larry Page

![Larry page](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

Because, in many ways, the dominant characteristic of Google is performance. Larry Page was adamant about this:

> Page also believed that the faster Google's search engine returned answers, the more it would be used. He fretted over milliseconds and pushed his engineers—from those who developed algorithms to those who built data centers—to think about lag times. He also pushed for keeping Google's home page famously sparse in its design because it would help the search results load faster.[[28](https://fortune.com/2014/11/18/larry-page-music-education/)]
